awd_titl_txt: FW-HTF-P: Office Work in the AI Age
awd_abstract_narration:
Office work is an important part of the American workplace across sectors, involving tens of millions of workers.  Further, doing office work is not just about the processing of paperwork and information; it also involves organizational knowledge, communication and relationship building, and other interpersonal skills.  These twin issues of job reliance and job complexity raise concerns for the design of artificial intelligence-based office automation tools that use software agents, machine learning, and data analytics.  Many such tools are designed without workers' needs or organizational complexity in mind; mistakes here can lead to reduced quality of life and job loss for workers, and worse outcomes for firms and customers.  This planning project will develop a multi-disciplinary research agenda toward the careful scientific study of both office work and the design of automation that affects it, with the goal of improving both office automation and training and outcomes for workers.

The project involves three main activities.  The first is a comprehensive literature review using a combination of the critical review method, the systematized review framework, and a review of state-of-the-art office automation systems.  The second involves qualitative analysis of a series of focus groups conducted with a broad sample of office workers about their daily work practices and challenges, their professional development and training, and their perceptions about the future of their job and of office automation.  The third main activity is a three-day ideation workshop that will build on the findings from the first two activities.  The research team will convene multidisciplinary academic and industry experts from human factors, computer science and artificial intelligence, economics, labor and human resource management, public policy, and equity and diversity to identify domains of office work and research themes that look most interesting, promising, and impactful for future research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Artificial intelligence is projected to have a significant impact on office work, office workers, and the economy as a whole. Office workers do more than just fill out paperwork; they also help coordinate tasks in the workplace, engage in everyday communication, and solve problems. But their work is a prime candidate for automation. Instead of implementing Artificial Intelligence for office tasks, and then managing the impact it creates on how office work is done and on job displacements, we should first know and understand how AI will specifically change the content and nature of office work. We must understand the role that office workers will play in an AI-driven work setting and use their skills and expertise, as well as technological capabilities, to design future office work. To understand what we should focus on in future research studies to better prepare ourselves for AI integration into office workplaces, we analyzed the research literature, interviewed office workers, held an ideation workshop with researchers and industry, and developed a research plan for Office Work in the AI age. 

Our findings suggest key areas for future research and development so that office workers can benefit from AI. First, our findings underscore the importance of doing research and implementation studies on education, training, and workforce development for office workers, as these will aid in defining the training and skill requirements in future workplaces.  In particular, office workers often have graduate degrees but find it difficult to advance in their careers. Office workers also work with data and database systems, so it is important to determine whether training opportunities that promote learning to work with data using data analytics tools, database systems, spreadsheet-based tools, and even AI-based tools, but with an emphasis on problem solving and decision making, will benefit office workers. Future research on workforce development should identify and create career pathways for office workers, especially in the context of an AI workplace,  so that they have opportunities for growth and can complement their skills with AI.  Second, our findings show that office workers frequently work with ineffective information systems. This points to a need for more user-centered evaluations and intelligent design of information systems used by office workers. In reality, designing smart information systems/databases for office work is one area where AI and other sophisticated technologies might help improve office workers' user experiences, skills, and long-term health and well-being.  Our findings also suggest that before AI is built or implemented, additional research should be undertaken to determine what office workers want and will benefit from. Finally, our findings also highlight the importance of health and well-being in the office, as well as the role that technology is already playing in promoting health in office work environments. 

Project outcomes will benefit office workers by highlighting their work, showcasing their unique skills in managing office work, presenting their needs and challenges, and outlining major research needs for future investigations, better policymaking, and the effective design of AI and other advanced technologies to benefit them. The project trained a STEM graduate student to recognize and assess emergent challenges in the future of work with artificial intelligence. 

These findings provide insight for future research and development that might be necessary to keep office workplaces and office workers coexisting with artificial intelligence and other advanced technologies in the future. These results also inform how researchers, industries, and organizations can design information technology, human resources, and work system infrastructure to better aid office workers and more effectively integrate AI into office workplaces.  A graduate course on the future of work was offered, with educational materials, such as syllabi with a list of research articles, tools, and techniques to enable students to engage in critical thinking about the future of work and their role in such systems. The results and recommendations from this work will be published in scientific journals and conference proceedings. 

 


Last Modified: 02/14/2024
Modified by: Priyadarshini Pennathur
